oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bethel Baptist Church: portrait of Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: West, Carroll Van
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color photograph of a portrait of Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth; African American male in suit; picture against a wood panel wall

Bethel Baptist Church was central to the struggle for civil rights in Birmingham, in large part because of the role played by Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth, who was pastor of Bethel from 1953 to 1961. Shuttlesworth founded the Alabama Christian Movement for Human Rights (ACMHR) in 1956 and his church acted as the administrative headquarters for the organization. The church was also home to the Movement Choir, which played a leading role in development of the protest music that was essential to the wider Civil Rights movement. Because of its leading role in Alabama civil rights activities, Bethel Baptist suffered three bombings, including a Christmas night bombing of the parsonage in 1956, from which Shuttlesworth emerged unharmed.
The church property, which is in the African American working-class neighborhood of Collegeville, was acquired in 1909 and the building was constructed in 1926 during the pastorate of Rev. Milton Sears. Many modifications have been done over time, including th
